subject: Personal Finance
title: The Three-Legged Stool
description: A quick, practical guide to The Three-Legged Stool.

hook.text: Retirement was meant to stand on three legs: Social Security, pensions, and personal savings. Two are wobbly.

buildup.text: Social Security was designed as a supplement, not a full income replacement. It covers about 40%.

discovery.text: Pensions have largely disappeared. In 1980, 38% of workers had pensions. Today it's under 15%.

twist.text: Personal savings now bear most of the weight â€” but most people aren't saving nearly enough.

climax.text: The shift from pensions to 401(k)s moved all risk from employers to employees who aren't investment experts.

punchline.text: The stool lost two legs. You're balancing on one.

quiz.question: What happened to the three-legged retirement stool?
options: Pensions largely disappeared and Social Security covers less
